entry.title: Combined summary - bitcoin taint & unilateral revocability (Re: ecash and revocability)
entry.summary: The lack of privacy in Bitcoin creates issues with tainted coins, which may become unspendable or only spendable at a discount. Despite the policy for Bitcoin stating that all coins are equally acceptable, people can unilaterally reject them based on their taint. However, revocability and taint inspection has not been an issue yet. Rejecting tainted coins would be detrimental to the usefulness of Bitcoin as a currency of common global adoption. Adam Back, a cryptographer who played an important role in the development of Bitcoin, raised concerns about taint and revocability in cryptocurrencies. He suggested a solution to the taint issue by committing to a payment and locking a coin without identifying oneself until the commitment is released. In an email exchange, Simon shares with Adam a privacy-enhancing solution based on fair exchange through bitcoin contracts and cut-and-choose. This solution would require a public pool of users who would be willing to exchange in common denominations at the same time, ensuring unlinkability while leaving a trace of exchange activity in the chain.
